threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content: @ByteWelder it's probably just DRAM that _also_ happens to have code in it

threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content: notice how flash, DIRAM, and IRAM all have `.text` linked into it

threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content: I can't remember how the ESP32 separates DRAM and IRAM. They might go into a different address space, or it could just be completely arbitrary and you're dividing your total RAM into two sections

threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content:
My hunch is that it's arbitrary due to this note:
> Any internal SRAM which is not used for Instruction RAM will be made available as DRAM (Data RAM) for static data and dynamic allocation (heap).

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/undocumented-backdoor-found-in-bluetooth-chip-used-by-a-billion-devices/

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: This kind of subversion was always certain. It exists as a matter of CCP policy

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: Simply put: they would have to be incompetent fools not to do it

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: See also: Huawei and other NOC equipment manufacturers

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: I guess the CCC folk who reverse engineered the firmware do though. They will speak up if this announcement proves incorrect

threads.author: pbearer
threads.content: I just came here to mention this too. This is wild!!

threads.author: pbearer
threads.content: Im just surprised they didn't hide it more thoroughly.

threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content:
Hold on. This is just silly though 
> Depending on how Bluetooth stacks handle HCI commands on the device, remote exploitation of the backdoor might be possible via malicious firmware or rogue Bluetooth connections.

> This is especially the case if an attacker already has root access, planted malware, or pushed a malicious update on the device that opens up low-level access.

threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content: They're saying there are HCI vendor specific commands that allow memory read/write, Mac address changing (this is fairly common) and LMP/llcp injection (again, fairly common, the upper layers of the stack sometimes need to manipulate link management at a low level)

threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content: Literally, if you have HCI command access to the controller you've already owned the device. What about this makes it a "backdoor"

threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content: Anyone who has worked at the hci level knows that vendors often include patch commands to the chipsets because they're usually ROM based with a way to patch code via RAM

threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content: A "rogue Bluetooth connection" cannot issue HCI commands. I'm doubting whether these researchers know that much about Bluetooth

threads.author: mike7c2
threads.content: I just read over this, the rhetoric severely misrepresents the issue, undocumented hci commands is sloppy but not an exploit in and of itself, certainly not one that let's someone own your device over BT

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: Doesn't mean that's not possible. Just not obviously

threads.author: mike7c2
threads.content: Sure, but nobody has discovered how to do that despite finding the funky hci commands

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content: Not yet

threads.author: cliffordheath
threads.content:
Code on an ESP32 acting as a Bluetooth for something else (in the same box, basically), and not careful of what commands it allows, might allow the something else, if it is compromised, to mess with the Bluetooth.

That is a very niche issue. And documenting may indeed be the â€œfixâ€.

threads.author: hard.fault
threads.content: Additionally pretty much every Bluetooth chip with some form of HCI is likely to have commands similar to this

threads.author: the_alchemist0
threads.content: What's up? I'm looking for someone to QC this ESP32-C3-Mini wiring schematic. The Espressif manual leaves several passive values as "TBD", and I'm not clear how to get the boot init and USB set up correctly. Important context: The USB is for JTAG; no normal serial comms required. Not serial flashing required; JTAG is fine. Ty!

threads.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
threads.content: You could always check Espressif's dev board schematics as a reference.

threads.author: the_alchemist0
threads.content: THe prob is, they all don't use USB JTAG

threads.author: the_alchemist0
threads.content: WHich also, blows my mind

threads.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
threads.content:
Here is a popular third party schematic with no USB to TTL chip on the board: https://files.seeedstudio.com/wiki/XIAO_WiFi/Resources/Seeeduino-XIAO-ESP32C3-SCH.pdf
Some info here: https://docs.espressif.com/projects/esp-hardware-design-guidelines/en/latest/esp32c3/schematic-checklist.html#usb

threads.author: the_alchemist0
threads.content: Thx!

threads.author: the_alchemist0
threads.content: Tangent: do you know what's up with the caps on the USB lines? That schm has them as DNP, the manual has them as TBD, and you don't use any for stm32

threads.author: the_alchemist0
threads.content:
Also, the inline resistors. Manual linked says 0hm (???), that schm has 22. 

My guess: don't add anything to the USB lines, tie IO8 and 9 high with a 10k R

threads.author: the_alchemist0
threads.content: I will probably yolo that, then troubleshoot A/R if it doesn't work

threads.author: the_alchemist0
threads.content: That schm has IO8 and 9 NC, which I am p sure is not correct

threads.author: the_alchemist0
threads.content: P sure that Seed board does NOT use JTAG

threads.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
threads.content:
GPIO 8 and 9 are strapping pins. If 8 is pulled up and 9 down, the chip will boot in download mode.
Have you read this description of the USB JTAG? https://docs.espressif.com/projects/esp-idf/en/stable/esp32c3/api-guides/usb-serial-jtag-console.html

threads.author: craig.atkin
threads.content: Remove the USB capacitors. Follow https://www.espressif.com/sites/default/files/documentation/esp32-c3-mini-1_datasheet_en.pdf section 9 as a reference. Capacitors labels TBD are not generally populated unless there is a pcb/hardware issue.

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: not neccessarily. if you overvolt the regulator, its not uncommon that it breaks and fails in a "shorted" way. meaning it connects the input to the output, and the voltage goes through to the next IC. does not have to, but it is possible

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
yep. thats a mentality of most modern code.
thats the reason why the esp32 has 4MB of flash and is STILL always full
thats the reason arduino code regularly overflows the device, despite the user not doing much more than some sensor reading and printing
thats the reason why browsers casually take 1GB per tab and think that is okay

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
First you define your attackers resources.
Random script kiddie? Already locked out by locking the flash.
Dedicated attacker with a few thousand to spend?
Government entity with essentially unlimited budget?

Most people just want to defend against 1, sometimes 2. Everything else is not reasonable.

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content: Also consider that in many cases, the attacker must have physical access to the device, which already changes the model

threads.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
threads.content:
If the board does not have a USB to TTL chip, you need to enable USB CDC.
```ini
build_flags =
  -D ARDUINO_USB_MODE=1
  -D ARDUINO_USB_CDC_ON_BOOT=1
```

threads.author: earth5418
threads.content: Thanks! so far as I've tested, it somehow works, can you explain to me why do I need to enable USB CDC?

threads.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
threads.content: If this is not defined, the Arduino framework will use the UART instead of USB CDC. Many boards have a USB to TTL chip that facilitates communication with your computer using the UART, so that is the default setting.

threads.author: earth5418
threads.content: Alright

threads.author: proforest1234_95641
threads.content: looking at your code i noticed you are changing the frequency of the i2c bus mid loop? as far as i know i2c uses one common clock speed for the entire bus and chaging it while one sensor is uploading can cause faulty readings, have you tried runnning both sensors at 100khz?

threads.author: proforest1234_95641
threads.content: the MAX30105 does have a 100kHz i2c standard mode

threads.author: proforest1234_95641
threads.content: Try using 100khz for the MAX30105 and let me know if it works.

omg_itsgollum69

threads.author: zecritic
threads.content:
It looks like that breakout board probably has a 5V -> 3.3V linear voltage regulator between the VCC header pin and the Vs pad on the ADXL345, but you're feeding VCC with 3.3V.

You could try connecting the 5V pin from your Xiao board directly to the VCC header pin instead of 3V3 from the Xiao board. (without connecting it to your red power rail on your breadboard, since I don't think anything else needs / wants 5V).

threads.author: omg_itsgollum69
threads.content: I also connected the CS pin to the 5V, I donâ€™t know if thats correct but thats what other people seem to do (https://wolles-elektronikkiste.de/adxl345-teil-1). 5V is probably a good idea so good point ðŸ‘

threads.author: omg_itsgollum69
threads.content: It still seems not to work tho

threads.author: zecritic
threads.content:
It looks like CS is already connected to Vddio through a pullup resistor, but it's hard to be certain without a schematic for that breakout board.
You could try grounding SDO to ensure I2C address 0x53 is selected. I had assumed it would have an internal pull-down, but the datasheet explicitly says it must be connected to either Vddio or ground.

threads.author: zecritic
threads.content:
For future reference, if you ever purchase a breakout board that has anything more than a voltage regulator and some caps on it, you should make sure it has a schematic. This board is simple enough that even with low-res photos I can guess the schematic, but for anything even mildly more complicated (or with a different color soldermask) it would be hard to figure it out.

Breakout boards are meant to save you time during prototyping, and having to reverse-engineer / guess how the breakout board works counter to that goal.

threads.author: zecritic
threads.content:
I have worked with it in the past, but I'm sure they've changed the libraries again since last I looked. There is a fair bit of complexity, some of which is intrinsic and some of which is AWS trying to maximize the usage of all of their services (OTA updates and "Jobs").

If you have specific questions, ask them here and people can try to answer them.

threads.content:

~~GPIO examples:~~

threads.author: almazkgz
threads.content: Thank you for the reply. I understand that that there is esp idf framework that I can use, but I want to interact with esp32 mcu without using the official framework. This is to understand how esp32 works. I also want to understand how build system and flasher work.

threads.author: bytewelder
threads.content: There are some projects out there that write a custom bootloader, but pretty much no-one talks to ESP32 directly.

threads.author: bytewelder
threads.content: I ~~probably~~ misread your initial question, sorry!

threads.author: bytewelder
threads.content:
You'll probably have to reverse engineer all the open source code:
https://github.com/espressif/esp-idf/blob/master/components/esp_driver_gpio/src/gpio.c
There's a custom flasher for web that you could analyze:
https://esphome.github.io/esp-web-tools/

threads.author: bytewelder
threads.content: You probably want to deep dive in to the "ESP32 Technical Reference Manual" wrt understanding how its GPIO works.

threads.author: bytewelder
threads.content: And keep in mind there might be differences between the different variants (ESP32, ESP32S3, etc.)

threads.author: bytewelder
threads.content:
For flashing/interacting with the ESP, there's this that you can analyze:
https://github.com/espressif/esptool

threads.author: gotbread
threads.content:
that will be an uphill battle.
if you want to test bare metal, go to a platform which has widespread support for it, e.g. stm32 or avr.
the esp32 offers you the framework, for anything else, you are on your own, good luck with reverse engineering that framework.

threads.author: bytewelder
threads.content: There are _some_ projects out there, like the wifi stack reverse engineering that's happened, but yeah, it'll be an uphill battle for sure.

threads.author: bytewelder
threads.content:
Speaking of which, this is a great video on a WiFi reverse engineering project:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r8IqkUTGjlA

threads.content: the question is, is that really a good learning project? learning bare metal is one project, reversing a framework another. there are better options for learning

threads.author: 637.8nm
threads.content:
I agree. If my understanding is correct, data is only meaningful when there is a clock and CS is pulled low.
I am away from my board, but I will test lowering the sample rate on my clone. I suspect 20kHz is OK?
SPI clock is set to 4 MHz, not sure if that's too high or too low. I see 200kHz as a "slow" rate on the IMU datasheet

threads.author: beer_baron
threads.content:
20khz is too low, you can play with triggers in pulse view, so that you can capture waveforms when CS goes low for example, that allows to have a much smaller buffer of samples and reliability in the capture (with triggers you can capture waveforms pre and post trigger too)

2gigassamples you have there is too much for a clone I doubt it is reliable, you just want to observe a transaction... 

I would set SPI clock to 1mhz and then the sample rate on pulseview to 10mhz, for example, that should be reliable for a clone, then play with the sample buffer size depending how long the transaction takes or ser a worst case value... A trigger can be cs low... If it doesn't trigger then something is not working on software / hardware side

threads.author: beer_baron
threads.content: When you have it working and no longer need to debug it, increase spi clock to the required value

threads.author: kingduken
threads.content:
Probably a few hardware things I would check:

Logic level voltages, i.e. 3.3V or if you need a level shifter

Make sure your Rx/Tx are not backwards

threads.author: kingduken
threads.content: And maybe a driver config thing I would check is how you're mapping `ttys0`, i.e. if you're mapping `getty` to `ttys0`

threads.author: bytewelder
threads.content:
Start with these:
https://github.com/espressif/esp-idf/tree/master/examples/get-started
Then perhaps peripherals:
https://github.com/espressif/esp-idf/tree/master/examples/peripherals
For the latter I'd start with GPIO and perhaps I2C.
A bit more advanced would be something like one of the basic http server examples:
https://github.com/espressif/esp-idf/tree/master/examples/protocols/http_server/simple/main

threads.author: bytewelder
threads.content:
If you try to write your own code for wifi and can't figure out why it doesn't find certain symbols, that's because the http samples depend on this component (a component is a dependency, a library):
https://github.com/espressif/esp-idf/tree/master/examples/common_components/protocol_examples_common
My next step was studying what this component did to understand how basic wifi and network was working.

threads.author: bytewelder
threads.content: But it all depends on what you want to build and which topics you want to learn. Perhaps WiFi isn't relevant to you.
